titleStmt.title: A single-phase V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi refractory high-entropy alloy with outstanding tensile properties

analytic.title: A single-phase V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi refractory high-entropy alloy with outstanding tensile properties

biblStruct.note: Received 14 November 2019; Received in revised form 13 June 2020; Accepted 15 June 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory high-entropy alloy Microstructure Tensile plasticity Solid-solution strengthening effect

div.p: A ductile V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi refractory high-entropy alloy (RHEA) with relatively low density (~6 g/cm À 3 ) is investigated, designed by controlling its valence electron concentration. The homogenized alloy exhibits a stable BCC structure, significant work hardening rate and considerable tensile stress (787 MPa) and elongation (21.9%). The solid-solution strengthening effect is estimated to be ~575 MPa by simplifying into a pseudo-binary alloy, which is in accordance with the test results. These findings can inspire a new strategy to design RHEA with a balanced matching of strength and ductility.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Recently, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) provide a new strategy to design materials, dealing with alloys composed of four or more principal elements [1,2]. Many unique properties are discovered in HEAs, including high strength-ductility synergy [3,4], ultra high Hall-Petch coefficient [5], excellent radiation tolerance [6] and superior magnetic properties [7]. As the representative type of HEAs, refractory HEAs (RHEAs) based on high-melting elements (Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) and Al are promising alternatives for superalloys [8,9]. It is reported that the high-temperature stress of RHEAs is clearly superior to the traditional Ni-based superalloys (Mar-M247 and Inconel 718), produced by the intense solid-solution strengthening (SSS) effect [10][11][12]. However, most of RHEAs display inferior ductility at room temperature (RT), which significantly restricts the commercial application. Notable exceptions include several ductile RHEAs with a single BCC structure, HfNbZrTi [13] and Hf-Nb-Zr-Ti-Ta [14][15][16], which exhibit the tensile strain (ε) of ~10% and yield stress of 550 MPã900 MPa. Nevertheless, these alloys possess high density (>8.5 g/cm 3 ) and price due to the rich of Hf and Ta.

In this context, our motivation is to explore a ductile RHEA utilizing V, Nb, Zr and Ti to reduce its cost and price. Earlier papers report that the equiatomic VNbZrTi alloy comprises a single-phase structure at as-cast condition but multiphases structure after annealing [17,18]. In addition, the compressive strain of this alloy is only 4.2% [19], which requires to improve its ductility. Knowing that the concentration of elements significantly affects the phase and mechanical properties in RHEAs [20,21]. For example, the AlNbTiVZr x alloys have B2 þ Zr 5 Al 3 phases when x < 0.25, while new C14 Laves phases are formed on this basis as increasing the content of Zr (x > 0.5) [22]. Varying the individual element from 11.11 at.% to 27.27 at.% in Mo-Nb-Hf-Zr-Ti alloy, the compressive yield stress and strain are in the range of 1200 MPa-1900 MPa and 5%-25%, respectively [23]. However, it is confused that how the composition affects the plasticity in RHEAs. Saad Sheikh [24] proposes a new method to optimize the intrinsically ductile RHEAs by controlling the valence electron concentration (VEC), which is well supported by the experimental data. Our previous work confirms that the ductility of single-phase RHEAs improves as the VEC decreases [16]. In V-Nb-Zr-Ti alloys, the VEC of V and Nb (group V) is higher than Zr and Ti (group IV). The deformability can be improved by adjusting the content of V and Nb appropriately.

In this paper, we prepare a novel V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy through vacuum arc melting. The VEC of this alloy is 4.33, which is lower than the VNbZrTi alloy (4.50). The microstructure, phase stability, tensile properties and SSS effect of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy are discussed.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: The alloy with nominal composition of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi was fabricated by arc melting using pure metal of V, Nb, Zr and Ti (>99.95 wt %). Two ingots, button-shaped samples (60 g by weight) and cylinder samples (500 g by weight), were re-melted at least 5 times inside a water-cooled copper cavity. The cast alloys were sealed in a quartz tube filled with argon to prevent any oxidation, and then homogenized at 1150 � C for 24 h.

Phase and microstructure were investigated via x-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 advanced diffractometer), scanning electron microscope (SEM, HITACHIS4800, equipped with electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) detectors) and fieldemission transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30). The XRD analysis used Cu K a1 radiation in a diffraction angle (2θ) ranging from 20 � to 90 � . Samples for TEM observation were the thin foil, which prepared through mechanical polishing and ion-beam thinned at a cold station of 100 K. To verify the phase stability, the thermal analysis of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy up to 1450 � C was carried out in a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, SETSYS EVOLUTION 16/18) at a constant heating rate of 10 K/min under flowing purified argon. The density of this alloy was measured by the Archimedes method using cylinder samples with the size of ϕ 10 mm * 10 mm. The flat tensile specimens with the gauge size of 10.2 mm *3.2 mm * 0.9 mm, were tested on the instron5569 electronic universal testing machine. The initial strain rate was set as 0.001 s À 1 .

div.head: XRD analysis
div.p: The XRD patterns of as-cast and homogenized V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloys are shown in Fig. 1. The diffraction peaks of as-cast alloys with 60 g (1#) and 500 g (2#) are similar, which comprises a single BCC phase structure corresponding to the space group of Im-3m. For convenience, the large ingot is adopted to investigate the structure characterization and tensile properties. The diffraction peaks (3#) of homogenized alloy shift slightly to higher 2θ compared to the as-cast alloy, indicating that the lattice parameter decreases. In a disordered solid-solution alloy, the 'theoretical' lattice parameter can be calculated by a rule of mixtures:
div.formula: a mix ¼ X n i¼1 c i a i (1)
div.p: where c i and a i are the atomic percent and lattice parameter of element i, respectively. The 'theoretical' lattice parameter of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is measured to be 3.34 Å (the lattice parameter of V: 3.03 Å, Nb: 3.30 Å, Zr: 3.58 Å and Ti: 3.27 Å). Moreover, the experimental lattice parameter can be calculated from the Bragg's Law: 2d*sin(θ) ¼ nλ, where θ corresponds to the diffraction of the first three strongest peaks. The error between "theoretical" and experimental results is only 0.01 Å ~0.02 Å, which also confirms that the BCC phase in as-cast and homogenized alloys is a disordered solid-solution structure.

div.head: Microstructure and chemical compositions
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2a, the as-cast V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy exhibits a homogenous dendrites microstructure. The bright part (pink arrow) and dark part (yellow arrow) correspond to the dendrite (DR) and interdendrite (IR), respectively. Compositions of them are shown in Table 1. The DR region and IR region are rich with high-melting Nb (2467 � C) and low-melting Ti (1670 � C), respectively. In addition, V (1890 � C) and Zr (1852 � C) with the moderate melting are almost uniformly distributed. The homogenized alloy shows the equiaxed grains morphology as shown in Fig. 2b. No second phases are observed, indicating that this alloy is composed of a single phase. The average grain sizes of as-cast and homogenized alloys are quantified by EBSD as ~198 μm and ~221 μm, respectively (Fig. S1 in supplementary information). The phase structure of homogenized alloy is confirmed by TEM furtherly (Fig. 2c~e). The selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) corresponding to the grain boundary region is well indexed by a single BCC structure. In addition, the lattice parameter calculated by highresolution image (Fig. 2e) is 3.37 Å, which is consistent with the XRD result.

Fig. 3 shows the distributed mappings of four elements in the homogenized alloy. All the elements are distributed uniformly, revealing that no secondary, ordering and clustering phases are formed. The atomic percentage of individual element (Table 1) is 33.06% (Ti), 16.54% (V), 33.42% (Zr), 16.98% (Nb), which is very close to the nominal composition.

div.head: Tensile properties
div.p: Fig. 4a shows the tensile stress-strain curves of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy. It can be derived that the as-cast alloy displays the yield stress of ~832 MPa, the ultimate tensile strength of ~913 MPa and the plastic elongation of ~18.6%. After homogenization, the stress decreases to ~787 MPa, but the elongation increases up to 21.9%. In addition, this alloy has an obvious strain-hardening effect (see inset in Fig. 4a). The fracture surface for homogenized alloy is shown in Fig. 4b ~ d, displaying the intergranular fracture morphology. However, the dense dimples with the size of ~50 μm are observed in the central position of cross section (Fig. 4d). This illustrates that the V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy shows the mixture of ductile and brittle fracture.

The density of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is ~6.10 g/cm 3 , which is lighter than that of VNbZrTi alloy (6.5 g/cm 3 ) [25,26]. For a better comparison of mechanical properties between homogenized V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy and various single-phase HEAs, the data of specific yield stress (SYS, defined as σ y /ρ) and true tensile strain (TTS) are plotted in Fig. 5. In particular, we classify the brittle or ductile RHEAs according to whether possessing tensile strain or not. Moreover, the TTS is considered to be zero, which is rational due to their limited compressive strain. The tensile SYS of brittle RHEAs is replaced by compressive SYS. It is apparent that the SYS of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy (~130 MPa*cm 3 /g) is much higher than the reported 3d-trainsition HEAs and ductile RHEAs. In fact, the yield stress of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is slightly lower than the reported ductile RHEAs, e. g. HfNbZrTi alloy (879 MPa) [13]. However, the density decreases by replacing Hf with V, resulting in the increasement of SYS. The 3d-trainsition HEAs possess high plasticity (ε > 35%) but low stress (σ y ) since the slip systems of FCC-type HEAs are easily activated. In addition, the density of 3d-transition HEAs is 8.0 g/cm 3 ~ 8.5 g/cm 3 . For these reasons, their SYS is only in the range of 15 MPa*cm 3 /g ~60 MPa*cm 3 /g. The SYS of brittle RHEAs has a wide spectrum of values, from 75 MPa*cm 3 /g to 205 MPa*cm 3 /g. Although the Al-containing RHEAs among them show higher SYS compared with V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy, most of them exhibit compressive strains <10% [20,21]. This indicates that these alloys are difficult to refine microstructure and remove casting defects by processing at room temperature, which restricts their application in structural materials.

div.head: Phase simulation and stability
div.p: Phase prediction is an important step in the design of novel HEAs. Some thermodynamics parameters including mixing enthalpy, ΔH mix , mixing entropy, ΔS mix , the differences of atomic size, δ r , single-phase ability, Ω (defined as T*ΔS mix /|ΔH mix |) are necessary to calculate. It is reported that the multi-principal alloys are tendency to form a single phase when À 15 kJ/mol �ΔH mix � 5 kJ/mol, 12 J/(K*mol) � ΔS mix � 17.5 J/(K*mol), δ r � 6.6% and Ω � 1.1 [39][40][41]. Table 2 summarizes the calculated results of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy, which meets these criteria.

Thermo-calc software has a high accuracy in predicting the phase formation of HEAs [42]. The calculation of the mole fraction of phases versus temperature for V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is shown in Fig. 6a. This alloy has a single BCC phase at the temperature from 418 � C to 1690 � C. As the temperature drops to lower than 418 � C, four phases including BCC, BCC_#2, HCP and HCP_#2 coexist at the equilibrium state. However, there are no obvious absorption peaks or release peaks in DSC curves (Fig. 6b) in this low-temperature range, indicating that the phase transformation does not occur. The V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy possesses a high melting (1902 � C) point and low atomic migration rate as reported HEAs [43,44], which brings difficulties in the phase transformation at ~ 420 � C. With the exception of annealing for extremely long time at low temperature, this alloy maintains a stable BCC phase.

div.head: Solid solution strengthening (SSS) effect
div.p: It is widely accepted that the solid-solution strengthening (SSS) in HEAs is attributed to the high atomic misfit and modulus misfit [10][11][12]. The SSS effect Δσ sss can be expressed as [45]:
where k is a fitting constant, setting as 0.1 is accepted in HEAs [14]. The G and c are the shear modulus and solute concentration, respectively.
The ε is the misfit parameter, which includes atomic misfit ε r and modulus misfit ε G . The relationship of ε with ε r and ε G is
div.formula: ε ¼ ε r þ βε G (3
div.p: here β is a dimensionless constant depending on the type of mobile dislocation. In a BCC crystal structure, each atom interacts with the 8 nearest-neighbor atoms to form a 9-atom cluster. The ε ri and ε Gi parameter can be estimated as:
div.formula: ε ri ¼ 9 8 X c j ε rij (4) ε Gi ¼ 9 8
div.p: X c j ε Gij (5) where c j is the atomic friction of j elements, ε rij and ε Gij can calculated from:
div.formula: ε rij ¼ 2 À r i À r j � r i þ r j (6) ε Gij ¼ 2 À G i À G j � G i þ G j (7
div.p: here r i and r j are the radius of element i and j, respectively; G i and G j are the shear modulus of element i and j, respectively. The atomic radius and shear modulus of V, Nb, Zr and Ti are shown in Table 3. The calculation of ε ri and ε Gi is shown in Table 4.

The data in Table 3 show that the radius of Zr and V has large differences with other elements, providing the most contribution of atomic misfit. As reported, RHEAs can be simplified into a pseudo-binary solid solution alloy to estimate the SSS [14]. To calculate the atomic misfit contribution Δσ r , we consider Zr and V as the solutes and the rest of Ti and Nb as solvents. In this case, the concentration c is 0.5. Ignoring for the atomic misfit of Ti and Nb, the calculation of ε r is 0.16 (|δ rV |þ|δ rZr |). By using Eq. ( 3), we can calculate the Δσ r ¼ 436 MPa. As for the modulus misfit, paring of V with the nearest-neighbor atoms contributes mostly.

Noting that the sum of ε Gi values for Nb, Zr and Ti is zero, the modulus misfit can be considered as the ε GV separately. In this case, β ¼ 2.0, c ¼ 0.167 and ε G ¼ 0.2 GPa. The SSS contribution is calculated to be Δσ G ¼ 139 MPa. The theoretical yield stress, σ yt can be predicted by:
div.formula: σ yt ¼ À σ y � mix þ Δσ r þ Δσ G (8
div.p: where the calculation of (σ y ) mix is 198 MPa-302 MPa by using the data in Table 3. The theoretical yield stress of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is estimated to be 773 MPa-877 MPa. Our experimental result of σ y is 787 MPa, which is in a good agreement with the above estimation.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: A novel V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is fabricated by vacuum arc melting successfully. This alloy exhibits a single BCC phase, which maintains a high structure stability up to1450 � C. The tensile yield stress, ultimate stress and true strain of homogenized alloy (1150 � C/24 h) are 787 MPa, 830 MPa and 21.9%, respectively. The comparable SYS (~130 MPa*cm À 3 /g) of researched alloy is much higher than the ductile RHEAs and 3d-trainsition HEAs with single phase, which attributes to its low density and high solid-solution strengthening effect.

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. (a) SEM images of homogenized V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy: (b)-(e) EDS mapping of V, Nb, Zr, Ti, respectively.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. Tensile properties and fracture morphology. (a) Tensile stress-strain curves of as-cast and homogenized V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloys at room temperature. The inset shows the corresponding strain hardening response (dσ/dε). (b) The plate tensile specimen with the gauge size of 10.2 mm *3.2 mm * 0.9 mm; (c) The fracture of homogenized alloy with low magnification; (d) Magnified the dimples indicated by the yellow rectangle of (c). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. Specific yield stress (SYS) versus true tensile strain of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy and reported single-phase HEAs [4,13,15,26-38].

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 6. (a) Phase simulation of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy utilizing a Thermo-Calc software with TTTi3 database (b) the DSC curves at the heating rate of 10 � C/min protected by Ar atmosphere.

figure.figDesc: Calculated results of the atomic misfit, |δ ri |, the modulus misfit, δ Gi in the BCC lattice structure of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: No conflict of interest exits in the submission of this manuscript. I would like to declare on behalf of my co-authors that the work was original research that has not been published previously, and not under consideration for publication elsewhere, in whole or in part. All the listed authors have approved the manuscript that is enclosed.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Yiwen Chen: Investigation, Methodology, Writing -review & editing. Ziqi Xu: Data curation. Meng Wang: Software. Yunkai Li: Supervision. Chao Wu: Supervision, Investigation. Ying Yang: Methodology.

div.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.msea.2020.139774.
